comments.commentBody:
The hero worship and idolization continues. "We love you" although we don't really know you.

College is as realistic as "Neverland", "Disneyland", or "Happy Valley", and the video reminds me of the positive, innocent spirit of youth.

However, it also makes me angry at the blind worship that made it easy for a narcisstic sociopath like Sardusky, to find his naive prey.

Congratulations America. Could these mildly progressive voting results mean that America will become a 20th century country again? Not a 21st century—that’s asking too much, but at least will it hold back our reversion to the 19th?

I guess I will have to give the citizens of Mississippi more credit than I had. I was one of those who was sent to Biloxi in the 1950s from California, to go to the AF electronics school there. Having grown up in a tolerant environment, in a middle class neighborhood, it was a real cultural shock to discover how people lived in the south, and their culture. When I left there I was not sure if they were even civilized. Of course being just out of Hi School, I was not really worldly, and was not a student of cultures. So I carried those prejudices with me for many years.

When I saw this proposed law for Mississippi, it only reinforced my stereotype of Mississippi. I have read quite a bit about the Civil War, and other American history for many years now, but Mississippi to me, has always seemed to me to be the backwater of the country. It has one of the lowest educational levels and one of the lowest economic levels of any state. It receives more federal money than it contributes, and yet their citizens denigrate liberal California, which sends some of the federal money that Mississippi gets.

So I actually was surprised when this oppressive law was defeated. Maybe it is a sign that the citizens of Mississippi are beginning to realize just how much their 19th century culture has cost them.
yippeeI more reason to exercise instead of working a bit more today.
Joe Frazier was a champion who conducted himself as a champion. RIP Mr. Frazier; you influenced my life.

Imagine if this was a guy named Mohammed Khan,offering namaz before a game and with Koranic verses painted on his cheeks.
How long before this guy would be called a terrorist ?

For all those defending Paterno, the fact that Sandusky reportedly continued to be involved with the football program up until last week speaks volumes for how seriously he and others took the allegation of "inappropriate behavior."

After reading more of the posts here I'm stunned by the level of denial on the part of the Joe Pa backers.  Really, he not culpable?  You folks need help, this is clearly on him.  I doubt Joe Pa tells his players or allows his players to get away with just the minimally excepted effort on the football field.   You don't win championship with just the minimal effort or minimal leadership!  Get some perspective and forget about his accomplishments on or off the football field - he failed do what he requires his players to do all of the time go the extra yard.  He could and should have stopped this long ago, but Joe Pa choice was to look the other way!

I would be impressed with Penn State if just one of its alumni posting here could complete an entire paragraph without a spelling error. I give up on expecting no grammatical mistakes.

As for Mr. Paterno - he covered up. He was given a detailed account by the grad student. He should have and could have done much more, but no, in an effort to avoid any scandal on his "tradition of integrity," he didn't pursue it. He is complicit. Therefore, he goes. It's not that hard.
Another case of the 1% making their own rules.  Instead of Raj we get Joe Pa. the former received 11 years and 92 million in fines.  The latter should do double that time.
Forget Joe's job; his responsibility as a person was to the child; And why didn't that grad assistant go into the shower and rescue that kid? They all need to go
Why don’t they simply shut down their program immediately? THIS  is much more shameful than I realised. I thought Coach Paterno was getting a bad rap. Now, I think he failed.
Penn State is a cesspool of filth.  This university's claim to fame has only ever been football and now it doesn't even have that.  What a despicable bunch of so called professionals.  Shame on them.

Read the indictment. It is disturbing.  A child is being raped and all Mr. McQuery could do was tell his father and Mr. Paterno after he saw this. Is this for real? A child is being raped and no one stopped the monster?  All of this for a job and a football program?  Mr. Paterno continued to see the monster on campus and did not do anything for 9 years.  He turned away.  He just did his legal duty of telling those responsible for the university.  Fire Joe Paterno and Mr. McQuery now!

The idea that Paterno did all that he should have done, and that to do more would make him a vigilante is ludicrous.

Your closest colleague is accused of raping a child in your facility (of which JP was essentially the CEO). You tell your HR contact, but never hear about a criminal investigation. Do you ever follow up with HR and say hey did you ever report that insanely criminal case that we talked about, like the law requires you to? No. Never.

Let's try it different. A teacher in your school reports seeing a 60-year old man pinning your 10-yr old son up against a shower wall (read the grand jury report). The principal later says, well, I mentioned it to the HR admin and nothing I guess ever came of it. Would you seriously say to your son, that principal, by obeying the letter of the law, did anything close to his moral duty?

These posts supporting JP seem farcical.

It seems that Paterno is considered expendible....he may not be legally liable, but there are moral and ethical obligations to be considered here -- the report of the rape of a 10-year old boy in a shower room is not the same as an accusation of being "overly friendly", as well as the fact that Paterno is on the board of the non-profit for which the accused offender worked/volunteered....also, educators are required by law to notify the police/social services in any suspected case of abuse (hence, the "may")-- in opposition, there have been reports that the accused wasn't working for the University at the time of the alleged incident, but, if so, who gave him access to the facilities?  And, in that light, why weren't the police called immediately, since the University would have had no investigative responsibility for or authority over a non-employee?  Lots of questions, but, in the end, a whole bunch of people should have stood up for the child, and all they did was act to protect themselves and each other -- too clever by half at the expense of a young boy (and, in effect, others like him, according to the criminal charges) considered to be immaterial to their career goals...now it's going to come down to the Board and Management trying to save their own jobs by taking action against Paterno -- he's not guiltless, but he almost certainly will be offered up in an attempt to save those at least equally, and apparently, much more responsible for this disgusting display of narcissism...in the end, all of the people who knew of the allegation and didn't notify the authorities should be terminated, but that is as unlikely as Paterno surviving the scramble for safety ongoing by those in power at Penn State.

Just how many Penn Staters does it take to right a wrong. We know eight is not enough...the GA, the GA father. two janitors, Paterno, Curley, Schultz and Spanier. Will the Board of Trustees do the right and proper thing and FIRE Paterno and Spanier. Stay tuned.

These posts supporting JP are ludicrous.

If a teacher saw a 60 yr-old man pinning your 10 yr-old son up against a shower wall naked, and reported it to the principal (read the grand jury report). And the principal said, "Well, I told the superintendent of schools and guess nothing came of it. Didn't want to be a vigilante! Never checked back once to see if there was an investigation!"

Would you really tell your son that the principal, who barely scraped a legal requirement, acted like a warm-blooded human being?

These posts supporting JP seem farcical.

A grave mistake that Joe will take to his grave. Perhaps we are all complicit in this wrong turn down the highway of life. We place much too great an emphasis on winning / money in college football and not enough on the responsibility of leadership. Say it ain't so Joe....Very hard to understand this alleged pedophile (assistant of 20 + years)  remained in the presence of young boys. It is impossible to understand why he was allowed on the campus with young boys. Joe you made a big mistake not taking this to the police. But, like Nixon it was the cover up of a heinous crime that will knock you off the winning streak and deservedly so.
Who is protecting our children?

I'm a couple of years younger than Joe P and I believe we have a generational problem.            Given what I under stand of the facts I would have acted the same way as Paterno. In a  corporate structure the problem is reported up the line to the level where people are authorized to speak for the company. Joe p would have been totally out of line running to the police with what hearsay evidence he knew. Those of us who served in the military were bound by the same constraints: report the problem up-the-line to the level where the authority exists to take corrective action. In the mores of our generation Joe P could have resigned but snitch to the police was not in the cards. As for the boys they would not have made it in the thirties.We were taught  how to handle perverts and being submissive was not an option.

is ? guess Europe

http://twitter.com/solarlife

It would be wise for pro-choice readers to stop congratulating themselves on the failure of Mississippi's personhood amendment. It is not a sign of the pro-life movement losing ground. The amendment failed not because Mississippi leans pro-choice after all, but because numerous pro-life organizations, including strongly pro-life Catholic and Methodist leaders, spoke out against it on the grounds that it would not, despite incredible volumes of misinformation from both sides, have actually banned abortions, birth control, or anything at all, even if unchallenged in court. In 1983, Akron v. Akron Center for Reproductive Health, the Supreme Court ruled that a state may not adopt a personhood theory as a means to regulate abortions. Yet the inevitable challenge to this personhood ruling was likely to strengthen existing court doctrine that guarantees a woman's right to an abortion, undermining the pro-life cause by jumping the gun with a load of nonsense.

Over the past several decades, pro-lifers at the forefront of their cause have done their research, and they know they will not ban abortion under the existing Supreme Court. The Mississippi amendment, at best, would have amounted to an official state opinion, much like an official state bird. The only way to ban abortion is to change the presidency, change the Supreme Court, and introduce an explicit criminal prohibition on the destruction of the unborn.

Sleep well tonight, but keep your eyes open going forward. The abortion debate is not over.

#62: "I certainly hope that people in Ohio stop complaining about the disappearing middle class. They just voted to continue the obscene transfer of their wealth to government unions."

==============

... because the transfer of wealth to Wall Street is so much more preferable.

Your comment is so full of holes that it almost isn't worthy of a response, but it bears noting that unions are far and away more worthy of keeping around than destroying altogether.

Besides, to cast police and firefighters, teachers, and sanitation workers as "overpaid" is utter nonsense, and you KNOW it.

Better the corruption of the unions than of the private sector, particularly when, despite corruption, unions are responsible for mandatory overtime pay, vacations, sick leave, workplace safety, and worker's compensation - in the public AND private sectors.

The message has been sent loud, clear, and HARD: public sector workers want a share of the pie they educate, serve, and protect, sometimes with their own lives. They're taxpayers, too, and they continue to make concessions with their wages and benefits - and they've had ENOUGH.

Get over it.
MEANS nothing. the republicans, born again crowd and other true believers will just keep on slashing away at those who don't agree with their perverse view of the world....
